revision.text:
The '''death row phenomenon''' is the emotional [[stress (medicine)|distress]] felt by [[prison]]ers on [[death row]]. Concerns about the ethics of inflicting this distress upon prisoners have led to some legal concerns about the [[constitution]]ality of the [[death penalty]] in the [[United States]] and other countries. In relation to the use of solitary confinement with death row inmates, death row phenomenon and '''death row syndrome''' are two concepts that are gaining ground. The death row syndrome is a distinct concept, which is the enduring psychological effects of the death row phenomenon, which merely refers to the triggers of the syndrome.
Harrison and Tamony<ref>[http://www.internetjournalofcriminology.com/Harrison_Tamony_%20Death_Row_Syndrome%20_IJC_Nov_2010.pdf Harrison, K. and Tamony, A. (2010). "Death Row Phenomenon, Death Row Syndrome and their Effect on Capital Cases in the US". November 2010. ''Internet Journal of Criminology''.] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110713050059/http://www.internetjournalofcriminology.com/Harrison_Tamony_%20Death_Row_Syndrome%20_IJC_Nov_2010.pdf |date=2011-07-13 }}</ref> define ''death row phenomenon'' as the harmful effects of death row conditions, while ''death row syndrome'' is the consequent manifestation of psychological illness that can occur as a result of death row phenomenon.
==Phenomenon== Death row syndrome is a psychological disorder that inmates on death row can go through when they are put in isolation. Inmates affected by death row syndrome may display suicidal tendencies and psychotic delusions. According to some [[psychiatrist]]s, the results of being confined to death row for an extended period of time, including the effects of knowing one will die and the living conditions, can fuel [[delusion]]s and [[suicide|suicidal]] tendencies in an individual and can cause [[insanity]] in a form that is dangerous.<ref name="Ross">Avi Salzman, "[http://www.scu.edu/news/rossdeathpenalty.cfm Killer's Fate May Rest on New Legal Concept]", [[Santa Clara University]], 1 February 2005.</ref> Prisoners wait years for execution on death row and while waiting the prisoners go through painful isolation. They live in cells the size of parking spaces. Living in this kind of condition can amplify the effects of isolation. Most of the inmates stay in their cells for more than twenty hours a day. This kind of isolation and waiting for execution causes many inmates to die naturally.<ref>Inglis-Arkell, 2014</ref>
The suicide rate of death row inmates was found by Lester and Tartaro to be 113 per 100,000 for the period 1976–1999. This is about ten times the rate of [[suicide in the United States]] as a whole and about six times the rate of suicide in the general U.S. prison population.<ref>"Suicide on death row", David Lester and Christine Tartaro, ''Journal of Forensic Sciences'', ISSN 0022-1198, 2002, vol. 47, no 5, pp. 1108–1111</ref>
Since the re-institution of the death penalty in 1976 to January 1, 2017, 145 prisoners have waived their appeals and asked that the execution be carried out. In the post-''[[William_Henry_Furman|Furman]]'' era, four states (Connecticut, New Mexico, Oregon, and Pennsylvania) have executed only volunteers.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://deathpenaltyinfo.org/information-defendants-who-were-executed-1976-and-designated-volunteers|title=deathpenaltyinfo.org|author=|date=|website=DeathPentaltyInfo.org|access-date=June 22, 2017}}</ref>
The theory of the death row phenomenon may be traced to 1989, when the [[European Court of Human Rights]] agreed that poor conditions on death row in [[Virginia]] should mean that a fugitive should not be extradited to the US unless the US agreed it would not execute the fugitive should he or she be convicted.<ref name="Ross" /> Additionally, the number of years that the fugitive would be on death row was considered problematic. The case is known as ''[[Soering v. United Kingdom]]''.<ref name="Smith">Rhona K.M. Smith, ''Textbook on International Human Rights'', second edition, Oxford University Press, 2005, p. 228.</ref> Earlier, however, in 1950, a justice of the [[United States Supreme Court]] in ''[[Solesbee v. Balkcom]]'' remarked that the "onset of insanity while awaiting execution of a death sentence is not a rare phenomenon". Often the death row phenomenon, being a result of a prolonged stay on death row, is an unintentional result of the long procedures used in the attempt to ensure the death penalty is applied only to the guilty.<ref name="Burns">''[[United States v. Burns]]'' (2001).</ref>
==Legal ramifications== {{As of|2013}}, arguments about the death row phenomenon have never been successful in avoiding the death penalty for any person in the US, but the [[Supreme Court of the United States|US Supreme Court]] has been aware of the theory and has mentioned it in its decisions. When a [[serial killer]] named [[Michael Bruce Ross]] agreed to be executed in 2005, this had also led to a legal dispute over whether he could ever legally agree to such a thing, as the death row phenomenon might have contributed to his decision.<ref name="Ross"/>
In Canada, the [[Supreme Court of Canada]] cited the death row phenomenon, along with a few other concerns about execution, to declare the risk of a prisoner being executed after he or she is extradited to another country to be a breach of [[fundamental justice]], a legal right under [[Section Seven of the Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms|Section 7]] of the [[Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms]] in the [[Constitution of Canada]]. The case was ''[[United States v. Burns]]'' (2001). Earlier, in 1991, some Supreme Court justices had, in ''[[Kindler v. Canada (Minister of Justice)]]'', expressed skepticism about the legal argument regarding the phenomenon, writing that the stress was not as severe a punishment as the execution itself, and writing that the prisoners themselves choose to appeal their sentences, thus being responsible for the prolonged stay on death row. In ''Burns'', however, the Court acknowledged that the mere process of execution, including making sure that the sentence is carried out justly, "seems inevitably to provide lengthy delays, and the associated psychological trauma." This cast doubt on whether the risk of execution after extradition, as a whole, could be compatible with the principles of fundamental justice.<ref name="Burns"/>
In [[Jamaica]], in the case ''[[Pratt v A-G of Jamaica|Pratt v Attorney General for Jamaica]]'', the death penalty was overturned for two prisoners by the [[Judicial Committee of the Privy Council]], who had made reference to the death row phenomenon. In these judges' opinions, the prisoners had been on death row for too long, and that too many appeals were allowed to the prisoners, who were forced by instinct to attempt to appeal and were thus confined to death row for too long.{{citation needed|date=August 2012}}
United States Supreme Court Justices opposing the death penalty, such as [[Justice Stevens]] and [[Justice Breyer]], have at multiple times argued in their [[dissenting opinion|dissents]] that the delay and waiting on death row was a factor making capital punishment unconstitutional as a cruel and unusual punishment. Their views were rejected by [[concurring opinion]]s from more conservative justices such as [[Justice Scalia]] and [[Clarence Thomas|Justice Thomas]], who said that this long delay was caused by the convicts themselves and by "Justices opposed to the death penalty."<ref>{{cite web|title=BAZE et al. v. REES, COMMISSIONER, KENTUCKY DEPARTMENT OF CORRECTIONS, et al. |url=https://www.law.cornell.edu/supct/html/07-5439.ZS.html |publisher=law.cornell.edu |accessdate=July 25, 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=GLOSSIP et al. v. GROSS et al. |url=https://www.law.cornell.edu/supremecourt/text/14-7955 |publisher=law.cornell.edu |accessdate= July 25, 2017}}</ref>
==Examples in fiction== * [[Fagin]] in ''[[Oliver Twist]]'' by [[Charles Dickens]] * ''[[The Seven Who Were Hanged]]'' by [[Leonid Andreyev]] * ''[[The Last Day of a Condemned Man]]'' by [[Victor Hugo]] * ''[[A Hanging]]'' by [[George Orwell]] * ''[[The Stranger (Camus novel)|L'Étranger]]'' by [[Albert Camus]] * ''[[Invitation to a Beheading]]'' by [[Vladimir Nabokov]] * ''[[The Green Mile (novel)|The Green Mile]]'' by [[Stephen King]] * ''[[The Pit and the Pendulum]]'' by [[Edgar Allan Poe]]
==See also== {{Portal|Criminal justice}} * [[Death anxiety (psychology)]] * [[Death row]] * [[List of United States death row inmates]]
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== * [http://www.deathpenaltyworldwide.org/death-row-phenomenon.cfm Death Row Phenomenon: Death Penalty Worldwide] – Academic research database on the laws, practice, and statistics of capital punishment for every death penalty country in the world.
{{capital punishment}}

{{Infobox Organization |name = First Nations Health Authority - FNHA |type = British Columbia Health Authority |motto = Health through wellness. |leader_title = CEO |leader_name = Joe Gallagher |website = [http://www.fnha.ca/ www.fnha.ca] }}
The '''First Nations Health Authority''' ('''FNHA''') is a health service delivery organization responsible for administering a variety of health programs and service for [[First Nations in BC|First Nations people living in BC]]. The FNHA is part of a [[First Nations]] Health Governance Structure in BC that includes the First Nations Health Council and First Nations Health Directors Association. The First Nations Health Authority emerged from a number of Tripartite agreements between [[BC First Nations]], the [[BC, Canada|Province of BC]], and the [[Government of Canada]] that included the Transformative Change Accord: First Nations Health Plan [2006],<ref>Transformative Change Accord: First Nations Health Plan http://www.health.gov.bc.ca/library/publications/year/2006/first_nations_health_implementation_plan.pdf</ref> Tripartite First Nations Health Plan [2007],<ref>Tripartite First Nations Health Plan [2007] http://www.health.gov.bc.ca/library/publications/year/2007/tripartite_plan.pdf</ref> and the Tripartite Framework Agreement on First Nations Health Governance.<ref>British Columbia Tripartite Framework Agreement on First Nation Health Governance: http://www.hc-sc.gc.ca/fniah-spnia/pubs/services/tripartite/framework-accord-cadre-eng.php</ref> A first for [[Canada]], the FNHA is the first province-wide First Nations Health Authority in Canada. The FNHA plans, designs, manages and funds the delivery of [[First Nations]] health programs and services in BC. These community-based services are largely focused on health promotion and disease prevention - such as: * Primary Care Services * Mental Health and Addictions Programming * Health Infrastructure * Environmental Health and Research * [[Non-Insured Health Benefits]]
The FNHA strives to improve First Nations health outcomes and close the gaps that exist between [[First Nations in BC|First Nations people in BC]] and the rest of the provincial population.<ref>Implementing the Vision: BC First Nations Health Governance. {{ISBN|978-0-9867697-0-2}} http://www.hc-sc.gc.ca/fniah-spnia/pubs/services/tripartite/vision-eng.php</ref> The FNHA serves both the urban and rural First Nations population that includes 203 communities throughout the province.
On October 1, 2013 the FNHA completed the second phase transfer of federal programs and services from Health Canada.<ref>Assembly of First Nations Congratulates the B.C. First Nations Health Authority on its Historic First Day http://www.afn.ca/index.php/en/news-media/latest-news/assembly-of-first-nations-congratulates-the-b.c.-first-nations-health-</ref><ref>B.C. First Nations take over their own health care services http://www.vancouversun.com/health/First+Nations+take+over+their+health+care+services/8979530/story.html</ref>
==See also== '''Other Health Authorities in British Columbia:''' *[[Fraser Health]] *[[Interior Health]] *[[Island Health]] *[[Northern Health]] *[[Provincial Health Services Authority]] *[[Vancouver Coastal Health]] *[[Health Canada]]

{{multiple issues| {{cleanup-reorganize|date=August 2013}} {{no footnotes|date=August 2013}} {{ref improve|date=August 2013}} {{Primarysources|date=January 2009}} {{advert|date=August 2013}} }} '''Introduction'''
FIAN International - formerly, FoodFirst Information and Action Network - was founded in 1986 as the first international human rights organization to advocate for the realization of the right to food and nutrition. Holding a consultative status with the United Nations Economic and Social Council, FIAN is active in more than 50 countries, through national sections and seeds groups, which account for 25 of these, as well as individual members and international networks. With no religious or political affiliation dictating its work, FIAN International exposes violations of people's right to food and related rights wherever they may occur and stands up against undue and oppressive practices that prevent people from feeding themselves.
By holding governments accountable, FIAN International strives to secure people's access to and control over natural resources and means of subsistence, crucial to ensure a life of dignity, now and for future generations. Nutrition, as an inherent component of the right to food, and a fundamental act of food sovereignty, remains a core objective in FIAN's work. As the struggle against gender discrimination and other forms of exclusion is an integral part of its mission, FIAN works with and in favor of the most marginalized and affected groups: its vision is of a world free from hunger, in which every woman, man, boy and girl can fully enjoy their right to food, as laid down in the Universal Declaration of Human Rights and other international human rights instruments.
FIAN International's Secretariat is based in Heidelberg, Germany, and Geneva, Switzerland.
'''Organizational Structure'''
FIAN is an international membership based organisation. FIAN's institutional members are its national sections which are legal entities in their own right and have their own membership and elected decision-making bodies.
Current sections of FIAN can be found in some 25 countries, for updates look at [http://www.fian.org/about-us/worldwide/ Worldwide].
The overall mission, vision and the strategy of FIAN is defined and revised by the International Council (IC), and represented by delegates of the sections who meet once every three years. The IC elects the International Executive Committee (IEC) -headed by the president, which supervises the implementation of FIAN’s strategic plans. The IEC meets bi-annually to review and strategize FIAN programs, methods and budgets.
The operative working unit being in charge of the execution of FIAN’s programs is its International Secretariat (IS) located in Heidelberg (Germany) and Geneva (Switzerland), and coordinated by the Secretary General.
'''FIAN International's work'''
FIAN uses various working tools to achieve the realization of the right to adequate food.
'''''Case-work and Interventions'''''
At international Fact Finding Missions, FIAN identifies and addresses human rights violations. FIAN interviews people threatened or affected by violations of their right to food and verifies the facts of a situation. Face-to-face contacts to local counterparts are established and serve as a basis for trustful co-operation. On request of those affected, FIAN reacts quickly, analyses the case and mobilises members and supporters worldwide to send out Urgent Action protest letters. Violations are also followed-up in long-term case-work by local FIAN action groups. In close co-operation with the affected communities, FIAN persistently approaches the responsible authorities and identifies breaches of right to food obligations. FIAN’s analysis is based on the [[International Covenant on Economic, Social and Cultural Rights]] as interpreted in the UN General Comments, in particular General Comment 12 on the right to adequate food. Existing recourse mechanisms and legal remedies under national and international human rights law are applied to provide redress to the victims.
'''''Lobby and Advocacy'''''
Reliable contacts and networks, a sound documentation of cases and two decades of experience provide a solid basis for effective lobbying and advocating the right to food. FIAN holds states, international institutions and private actors accountable at the national and international levels. The Right to Food Guidelines adopted by the [[FAO]] in 2004 is one of the tools FIAN uses to monitor states’ right to food policies. FIAN tries to improve the existing right to food protection system and to establish new instruments. Intense follow-up work strives to secure the effective implementation of existing instruments, making the right to food politically and judicially enforceable everywhere for everyone.
'''''Information and Education'''''
Targeted information campaigns and awareness-raising on the right to food are at the core of FIAN’s work - to empower social movements and non-governmental organizations to hold states accountable for violations of the right to food, to clarify for governments and other duty-bearers the content and implementation needs of their obligations, and to motivate supporters from civil society to join action against human rights violations. The systematic information gathered from more than 400 individual cases over the past two decades is analyzed and fed into various professional publications.
'''Impact'''
FIAN was involved prominently in the development of the human rights protection system, for instance in the strengthened procedure of State’s and parallel reporting on economic, social, and cultural human rights in the UN human rights system; the elaboration of the UN General Comment No. 12 on the Right to Food in 1999 as the most authoritative legal interpretation of the right to food in international law; and the adoption of the “Voluntary Guidelines on the Right to Food” by the FAO member states in 2004.
'''''FIAN’s commitment was awarded internationally:'''''
'''Public Eye on Davos - Positive Award:''' In 2006, FIAN International together with two partners won the Public Eye on Davos - Positive Award, which is given every year on the occasion of the World Economic Forum in Davos, for their commitment in favour of the rights of workers of the Mexican tyre factory Euzkadi.
'''Silver Rose Award:''' In 2005, two staff members of the FIAN Section Germany received the Silver Rose Award for their commitment for the rights of workers in the flower industry, the participation in the development of the International Code of Conduct for the Production of Cut flowers (ICC) and its successful implementation in the framework of the Flower Label Programm (FLP).
==External links== *[http://www.fian.org FIAN International] Face-It-Act-Now Campaign: http://www.face-it-act-now.org/ Urgent Actions: [http://www.fian.org/get-involved/take-action/urgent-actions/ http://fian.org/cases/letter-campaigns] Publications: [http://www.fian.org/library/publications/ http://fian.org/resources/documents/others]

{{good article}} On June 2, 2012, '''Feng Jianmei''' ({{zh|s=冯建梅|p=Féng Jiànméi}}) was [[Forced abortion|forced to have an abortion]] in [[Zhenping County, Shaanxi|Zhenping County]], [[Shaanxi]], [[China]], when she was seven months pregnant with her second child. Local officials had demanded that Feng and her husband pay a 40,000 [[Chinese yuan|yuan]] fine for violating the nation's [[one-child policy]]. When they were unable to do so, authorities arrested Feng, made her sign an agreement to have an abortion, and held her down while injecting her with an [[abortifacient]]. Feng was reportedly traumatized by the incident and in poor health afterwards.
On June 11, Feng's family posted graphic pictures of her stillborn child. The images soon became a [[viral phenomenon]], sparking controversy within China and drawing international attention to the issue of forced abortions. In response to national and international attention, the Chinese government launched an investigation. On June 26, the investigation determined that Feng was not legally entitled to a second child, but that her rights had nonetheless been violated by the local family planning bureau, and as a result, two officials were fired and five others punished. On June 27, the [[National Population and Family Planning Commission]] announced it would send inspection teams across China to review the practices of local family planning divisions. Feng's husband, Deng Jiyuan ({{zh|s=邓吉元|p=Dèng Jíyuán|links=no}}), hired a lawyer to pursue criminal charges, but ultimately the family decided to settle out of court.
The incident led to increased scrutiny of China's one-child policy, both nationally and internationally. Feng's case has been cited in editorials critical of the one-child policy, and has also been used as an example of how the Internet is empowering ordinary people in an environment of government censorship. On July 5, [[European Parliament]] passed a resolution condemning both Feng's case and forced abortion in general. On January 1, 2016, after months of discussion, China's one-child policy was replaced with a [[two-child policy]].
==Background== ===One-child law=== {{see also|one-child policy|abortion in China}} Since 1979, Chinese couples have been limited to one child by law in order to control the country's population. Families living in rural areas, as well as those with an [[Ethnic minorities in China|ethnic minority background]], can often receive an exemption from the law and have a second child without penalty. Otherwise, couples who have two or more children are required to pay a fine to the government. According to He Yafu, an independent [[demographer]], such fines are common and "have become a major source of profit for family planning authorities" in recent years.<ref name=fury /> The demographer He adds that the fines allow wealthy families to have extra children while forcing poorer families into involuntary abortions.<ref name=fury /> The fines generate an estimated 20 billion [[Chinese yuan|yuan]] per year in revenue for the government.<ref name=fury /> He Yafu estimates that over 2 trillion yuan (~$314 billion USD) has been collected since 1980.<ref name=brutal />
China's Population and Family Planning Law prohibits infringement on people's personal rights and property for family planning purposes.<ref name=fury /> Moreover, a 2001 law prohibited abortions after the sixth month of pregnancy.<ref name=sparks /> Nevertheless, human rights groups and critics of the one-child policy say that these laws are inconsistently enforced, and the local officials in many areas still carry out forced sterilizations and/or coerced abortions, sometimes in the third trimester after the fetus has reached [[Fetus#Viability|viability]].<ref name=fury /><ref name=sparks /><ref name=CECC>Congressional-Executive Commission on China, [http://www.gpo.gov/fdsys/pkg/CHRG-110hhrg45233/pdf/CHRG-110hhrg45233.pdf 2008 Annual Report], 31 October 2008, p 98.</ref> In ten Chinese provinces, including Shaanxi, authorities are permitted to take "remedial measures" to ensure that birth quotas are not exceeded. In eight other provinces, authorities are required to terminate unauthorized pregnancies.<ref name=CECC/> Activists such as [[Chen Guangcheng]] have been jailed by the Chinese government for bringing to light evidence of forced abortions.<ref>{{cite news |title=Chinese to Prosecute Peasant Who Resisted One-Child Policy |work=Washington Post |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2006/07/07/AR2006070701510.html |date=8 July 2006 |author=Philip P. Pan |accessdate=28 April 2010}}</ref> In 2005, Chen filed a class-action lawsuit on behalf of women forced into [[sterilization (medicine)|sterilization]] or abortions and subsequently spent seven years in jail or under house arrest before emigrating to the United States in 2012.<ref name=suspends>{{cite news|title=China Says It Suspended Officials in Forced-Abortion Case|author=Josh Chin|author2=Olivia Geng|date=June 15, 2012|work=Wall Street Journal|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10001424052702303410404577468170016159682|accessdate=June 24, 2012}}</ref>
===Feng Jianmei=== In October 2011, Feng Jianmei, who was a 22-year-old woman from the small village of Yuping in Zeng Jia Township, [[Shaanxi]] province, became pregnant with her second child.<ref name=fury>{{cite news|title=Fury over 'forced abortion'|author=Yan Shuang|date=June 14, 2012|work=Global Times|url=http://www.globaltimes.cn/content/714855.shtml|accessdate=June 23, 2012}}</ref><ref name=pressure /> She had married in 2006 and given birth to a girl in 2007.<ref name=mature>{{cite news|title=Mom allegedly forced to abort mature fetus|work=Shanghai Daily|date=June 14, 2012|url=http://www.shanghaidaily.com/article/?id=503694&type=National|subscription=yes}}</ref> After listening to the advice of relatives, Feng and her husband, Deng Jiyuan, had believed they would be allowed to have a second child since they had waited five years between children and lived in a rural area.<ref name=ChinaNet>{{cite news|script-title=zh:陕西孕妇被引产调查|author=Jiang Yue|author2=Lei Ying|work=ChinaNet|date=June 19, 2012|publisher=21cbh.com|url=http://www.21cbh.com/HTML/2012-6-19/0NNTg3XzQ1NzA0Nw.html|accessdate=July 26, 2012|language=Chinese|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120624024046/http://www.21cbh.com/HTML/2012-6-19/0NNTg3XzQ1NzA0Nw.html|archivedate=June 24, 2012|df=}}</ref> According to [[Zhenping County, Shaanxi|Zhenping County]] officials, authorities had contacted Feng in March 2012 and told her that she needed to obtain documentation, including a new [[Hukou system|household registration]] (referred to as ''hukou''), in order to file an application to have the child.<ref name=fury /><ref name=form>{{cite news|title=A forced abortion for a mother who failed to sign a form|author=Malcolm Moore|date=June 14, 2012|work=The Telegraph|publisher=The Age|url=http://www.theage.com.au/world/a-forced-abortion-for-a-mother-who-failed-to-sign-a-form-20120615-20eu6.html|accessdate=June 24, 2012|location=Melbourne}}</ref> Her family denies this, saying that officials did not notify them until several days before the abortion was induced.<ref name=fury />
==Abortion==
Around May 28, local family planning officials phoned Feng to try to persuade her to have an abortion.<ref name=ChinaNet /> The attempt was unsuccessful, so on May 30 they visited the family house while Feng's husband was away at work. At first, authorities tried to persuade her to voluntarily have an abortion.<ref name=addiction /> After several hours, she told the officials she was going out to buy food, and left them in her living room.<ref name=addiction /> Instead, she went to an aunt's house, but around 15 officials followed her.<ref name=addiction /> They did not immediately arrest Feng, instead setting up shifts to keep watch over her at the aunt's house. Early the next morning, Feng escaped, causing the guards to panic.<ref name=ChinaNet /> She flagged down a van and persuaded the driver to help her.<ref name=addiction /> The driver let her out down the road, and Feng hid in hillside brush for the next 14 hours, waiting for the cover of darkness in the cold and rainy weather.<ref name=ChinaNet /><ref name=addiction /> When night came, she went to a relative's house in the countryside, where she hid under the bed.<ref name=addiction /> Authorities from the family planning office found her regardless, and allegedly assaulted her.<ref name=brutal /><ref name=WRWF /> They let her get a night's sleep before taking her to the hospital on June 2. Several witnesses reported that four men carried Feng out of the house with a pillowcase over her head.<ref name=addiction />
Simultaneously, family planning officials were in communication with Feng's husband, Deng Jiyuan. On June 1, they demanded that Deng either transfer his wife's residency status on the next day or pay 100,000 yuan (US$15,700) to the birth-planning social security fund.<ref name=addiction /> Transferring the residency status in one day was impossible, but Deng negotiated the payment down to 30,000 yuan before returning to Zhenping County (he actually only had 18,000 yuan that he had borrowed from work, but hoped an [[IOU]] would cover the balance).<ref name=addiction /> On his way back, Deng received a [[text message]] that demanded that he immediately pay the fee, which was now 40,000 yuan, and "not a penny less".<ref name=addiction /> Other family members received similar text messages.<ref name=fury />[[File:Feng Jianmei.jpg|thumb|A [[pixelation|censored]] image of Feng, posted on Sina Weibo by her family <!-- An unobscured version is available under [[#External links|external links]] -->|alt=A woman lies on a bed, staring blankly; next to her is a bloody baby that is partially obscured by computerized blurring]]
At the hospital, two men forced Feng to apply her thumbprint to a consent form and sign a document authorizing the abortion.<ref name="fury" /><ref name="sparks">{{cite news|title=China forced abortion photo sparks outrage|work=BBC News|date=June 14, 2012|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-asia-china-18435126|accessdate=June 23, 2012}}</ref><ref name="addiction" /> She was taken into an operating room and restrained by two men as she was injected with a poison to kill the fetus.<ref name="fury" /><ref name="addiction" /> Feng later told [[All Girls Allowed]], an American group campaigning against the one-child policy, "I could feel the baby jumping around inside me all the time, but then she went still."<ref name="form" /> She had been seven months pregnant at the time, so the abortion, voluntary or not, was illegal under Chinese law.<ref name="sparks" /> No family members were allowed to be present for the procedure.<ref name="mature" /> After the child died of [[Intrauterine hypoxia|hypoxia]], Feng underwent induced labor and delivered a [[stillbirth|stillborn]] girl on June 4.<ref name="mature" /> Feng later told All Girls Allowed: "It was much more painful than my first childbirth. The baby was lifeless, and she was all purple and blue."<ref name="AGA">{{cite press release|title=Officials forcibly abort the baby of Feng Jianmei, who was 7 months pregnant|publisher=All Girls Allowed|date=June 12, 2012|url=http://www.allgirlsallowed.org/forced-abortion-shocks-international-community|accessdate=June 25, 2012}}</ref> The corpse was then placed next to Feng on her bed for her family to dispose of when they arrived.<ref name="addiction" /><ref name="gruesome" />
Feng was traumatized by the procedure and smashed the door and cabinetry of a nurse's office in a fit of rage.<ref name=addiction /> A week later, Deng told ''The [[South China Morning Post]]'', "My wife is not well. She is sad and distressed. Sometimes she becomes emotional and confused."<ref name=SCMP /> Feng reportedly had a severe headache for several weeks after the abortion and attempted suicide multiple times.<ref name=AGA /> On June 15, an uncle told reporters Feng was in poor health and unable to eat.<ref name=suspends /> On June 26, Feng was still in the hospital and suffering from headaches.<ref name=pressure /> She told reporters that she wanted to go home, but that hospital staff would not allow her to leave. On June 29, her family reported that Feng would be released the next day.<ref name=resurfaces /> However, her condition worsened, and she did not return home until July 10.<ref name=settlement>{{cite news|title=China Settles Over Forced Abortion|author=Josh Chin|date=July 11, 2012|work=Wall Street Journal|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10001424052702303567704577519914257120978|accessdate=July 11, 2012}}</ref>
Deng filed an official complaint with [[Ankang]]'s petition office.<ref name=SCMP /> A deputy mayor allegedly told Deng that they would investigate, but when nothing appeared to be happening, Deng posted his family's story online.<ref name=SCMP /> later telling CNN that "I'm angry and want justice."<ref name=outrage /> Meanwhile, the township officials had prepared a statement that said Feng was of sound mind and body when she signed the consent form authorizing the abortion.<ref name=addiction />
==Aftermath==
===Story goes viral=== Feng's sister-in-law and Deng Jiyuan's sister, Deng Jicai ({{zh|s=邓吉彩|p=Dèng Jícǎi|links=no}}), came back from [[Hubei]] the day after the abortion and brought a video camera with her to film Feng. A family planning official, who discovered the tape, then demanded that it be erased.<ref name=addiction /> However, Jicai was able to capture several pictures with her cell phone.<ref name=addiction /> On June 11, a picture of Feng lying in a hospital bed "staring at the ceiling with dull eyes" next to the bloody corpse was posted on Chinese [[social media]] website [[Sina Weibo]], along with an image of a threatening text message sent by authorities.<ref name=mature /><ref name=form /> The images prompted outrage, and news of the event spread quickly.<ref name=sparks /> Angry comments from around China poured in, with people calling the authorities' actions "an atrocity", "the same as murder."<ref name=mature /><ref name=SCMP /> Many comments called for an end to the one-child policy, or tied the case to other controversial topics such as the corruption of local officials or the country's rural-urban divide.<ref name=brutal /><ref name=caught /> Many posts were quickly deleted by government censors.<ref name=gruesome>{{cite news|title=Gruesome photos put spotlight on China's one-child policy|author=Bo Gu|work=NBC News|date=June 14, 2012|url=http://behindthewall.msnbc.msn.com/_news/2012/06/14/12222877-gruesome-photos-put-spotlight-on-chinas-one-child-policy|accessdate=June 24, 2012|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120617042544/http://behindthewall.msnbc.msn.com/_news/2012/06/14/12222877-gruesome-photos-put-spotlight-on-chinas-one-child-policy|archivedate=June 17, 2012|df=}}</ref> Nonetheless, by June 13, more than 40,000 comments about the photos were present on Sina Weibo, and by June 15, images of Feng were among the most forwarded. "Seven-months pregnant forced abortion" was the website's top search term, and more than one million user comments were logged on the topic.<ref name=suspends /><ref name=forced>{{cite news|title= Seven-month-pregnant woman forced to abort|publisher=Al Jazeera|date=June 13, 2012|url=http://blogs.aljazeera.net/blog/asia/7-month-pregnant-woman-forced-abort|accessdate=June 25, 2012}}</ref><ref name=NewYorker /> Discussion also spread to other social media outlets, including [[NetEase]], where threads critical of the government were quickly locked to prevent further discussion.<ref name=family />
[[Zhang Kai (lawyer)|Zhang Kai]] ({{zh|s=张凯|p=Zhāng Kǎi|links=no}}), a lawyer known for his representation of the disadvantaged, posted the story on his blog.<ref name=fury /> [[Li Chengpeng]], a Chinese blogger with at the time more than five million followers, learned of the story and wrote "the purpose of family planning was to control population, but now it has become murder population ... If this evil policy is not stopped, this country will have no humanity."<ref name=gruesome/> Zhao Chu, a writer decried the one-child policy as a "profit-oriented activity that everyone hates", writing "this is not about enforcing the policy, it is about depriving someone’s right to live".<ref name=gruesome/><ref name=caught /> [[Liang Jianzhang]], chief executive of [[Ctrip]], called Feng's case "outrageous and violent" and "not unique to Shaanxi",<ref name=brutal /> saying that "abolition of the absurd family-planning policy is the only way to root out this kind of evil".<ref name=brutal />
Local newspaper ''Hua Shang Bao'' ran a story on Feng.<ref name=addiction />On June 12, human rights activist [[Huang Qi]] also posted the story and images.<ref name=WRWF>{{cite web|title=BREAKING: (Warning, graphic image) Chinese Woman Forcibly Aborted at Seven Months|author=Reggie Littlejohn|date=June 12, 2012|url=http://www.womensrightswithoutfrontiers.org/blog/?p=667|accessdate=June 24, 2012}}</ref> The story was then picked up by major media outlets throughout China.<ref name=reported>{{cite news|title=Forced Abortions Reported|work=Radio Free Asia|date=June 12, 2012|url=http://www.rfa.org/english/news/china/forced-abortion-06122012121318.html|accessdate=June 24, 2012}}</ref> On June 14, state-backed newspaper ''[[Global Times]]'' reported that "online posts about Feng's forced abortion had triggered a torrent of criticism directed at the Zhenping government and sparked debate about the national family planning policy".<ref name=fury /> On his personal Weibo account, chief editor [[Hu Xijin]] wrote, "I strongly oppose the barbarous forced abortion", saying the country's family planning enforcement needed to change.<ref name=brutal /> However, he stated that overall the one-child policy was a good thing, writing that "the world resources cannot afford to feed a China with billions of people".<ref name=brutal />
On June 13, French news agency [[Agence France-Presse]] reported that the graphic images of Feng and her stillborn child "have caused an uproar in China".<ref name=uproar>Agence France-Presse (June 13, 2012), "[http://www.bangkokpost.com/news/asia/297903/forced-abortion-picture-causes-uproar-in-china Forced abortion' picture causes uproar in China]", Retrieved October 23, 2012</ref> [[Al Jazeera]] also ran a story about Feng that day.<ref name=forced /> The next day, [[BBC]], [[CNN]], ''[[The Age]]'', and other major media outlets around the world ran articles on the topic.<ref name=sparks /><ref name=form /><ref name=outrage />
===Chinese government response=== After the story of Feng Jianmei's abortion gained widespread domestic and international exposure, Zhenping County officials denied the allegations, saying that the abortion was legal and that Feng had requested it.<ref name=fury /> "Feng agreed to go through an operation to end the pregnancy on June 2 following repeated mediation by the township officials", read the county's website.<ref>{{cite news|title=Chinese authorities force abortion in Shaanxi Province: report|agency=Japan Economic Newswire|date=June 13, 2012}}</ref> They further stated that she did not have a local ''hukou'' registration and that the couple was not entitled to a second child.<ref name=fury /> The statement was later removed, with a search for Feng's name causing an "error" message.<ref>{{cite news|title=How China's Forced Abortion Policy Hits Two Women|author=Gloria Riviera|date=June 14, 2012|url=http://abcnews.go.com/International/chinas-forced-abortions-child-rule-hits-women/story?id=16558428#.T-it4ZG8jbz|accessdate=June 25, 2012}}</ref> A few days later, local family planning official Yuan Fang stated the request for 40,000 yuan was "a deposit" that would have been returned after Feng filed the necessary paperwork.<ref name=form />
A hospital employee acknowledged that Feng was staying there and that the hospital "implements" family planning policy and "provides services" to that effect, but denied that forced abortion was a part of what they do.<ref name=reported /> He said he didn't know the details of Feng's case but stated that "she is probably just exaggerating things on the Internet".<ref name=reported /> It was soon revealed that the Zeng Jia Township had failed to reach its enforcement quotas under the one-child policy for the past two years, so it had received a "yellow card" warning.<ref name=form /><ref name=addiction /> Desiring to remove the warning, town officials decided to crack down on enforcement in June 2012.<ref name=addiction />
Approximately ten days after the forced abortion occurred, the Shaanxi Provincial Population and Family Planning Commission launched an investigation.<ref name=fury /> On June 13, Yu Yanmei, the deputy head of Ankang, visited the Deng household.<ref name=form /> Two days later, the commission concluded that Feng had indeed been forced into an illegal abortion,<ref name=sparks /> writing, "Such practice has seriously violated the relevant policies ... harmed the image of our family planning work, and caused extremely poor effects in society."<ref name=sparks /> Three officials, including the head of the local family-planning department, were suspended from their jobs on June 14.<ref name=suspends /> An employee of the Ankang Family Planning Bureau said that "grass-roots comrades aren't stupid, but this is what they're forced to do ... This is a problem with the entire system."<ref name=suspends />
The Ankang city government promised to "pursue strict legal and disciplinary action" once the investigation was finished.<ref name=suspends /> On June 14, the city issued a formal apology. "Since the illegal actions by some officials have seriously hurt Feng Jianmei and her family, we want to offer our deep apologies to them and to the generic public", read the statement.<ref name=outrage>{{cite news|title=Forced abortion sparks outrage, debate in China|author=Steven Jiang|date=June 14, 2012|publisher=CNN|url=http://www.cnn.com/2012/06/14/world/asia/china-abortion/index.html|accessdate=June 25, 2012}}</ref> The same day, deputy mayor Du Shouping visited Feng in the hospital to express the city's "sincere apologies."<ref name=suspends /> "I hope we can earn your forgiveness," he said in a statement published on the city's webpage.<ref name=suspends /> The Chinese government also said it had released a pamphlet emphasizing that [[late termination of pregnancy|late term abortion]] is prohibited and that the legal rights of pregnant women should be maintained.<ref name=SCMP>{{cite news|title=Late-term abortion forced on woman|author=Zhuang Pinghui|date=June 14, 2012|work=South China Morning Post}}</ref>
On June 26, the results of the investigation were announced. The investigation concluded that Feng was not entitled to have a second child due to her non-agricultural hukou, and that she had been told to fix her registration in March.<ref name=punished>{{cite news|title=Officials punished for NW China forced abortion|agency=Xinhua|work=China Daily|date=June 27, 2012|url=http://www.chinadaily.com.cn/china/2012-06/27/content_15524501.htm|accessdate=June 27, 2012}}</ref> However, Feng's rights were violated by county officials and there was no legal basis for the demanded 40,000 yuan fee.<ref name=punished /> "The incident showed that some officials at the grassroots level have a weak sense of the law and show little concern for the well-being of the people", the report said.<ref name=sacks>{{cite news|title=China sacks officials in forced abortion case|author=Tania Branigan|date=June 27, 2012|work=The Guardian|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2012/jun/27/china-sacks-officials-forced-abortion|accessdate=June 27, 2012|location=London}}</ref> The head of the family planning bureau of Zhenping, Jiang Nenghai, and one other official were fired.<ref name=pressure /><ref name=punished /> Five other government and hospital employees received some form of punishment.<ref name=pressure>{{cite news|title=Forced to Abort, Chinese Woman Under Pressure|author=Edward Wong|date=June 26, 2012|work=New York Times|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2012/06/27/world/asia/chinese-family-in-forced-abortion-case-still-under-pressure.html|accessdate=June 26, 2012}}</ref> Additionally, the county government was ordered to provide Feng with a living stipend.<ref name=pressure />
===Litigation=== Of the government's actions, Deng Jicai said, "Of course we're not satisfied with the result."<ref name=family>{{cite news|title=Family members of forced abortion victim in China cite continued harassment|author=Steven Jiang|date=June 27, 2012|publisher=CNN|url=http://www.cnn.com/2012/06/27/world/asia/china-forced-abortion/index.html|accessdate=June 27, 2012}}</ref> She added, "all they've done is punish a few leaders, but they haven't done anything to the people directly responsible for dragging my sister-in-law [Feng] in to have an abortion. They haven't pursued a single person for criminal liability."<ref>{{cite news|title=Chinese Woman in Forced-Abortion Case Says She Is Being Held in Hospital|author=Josh Chin|date=June 27, 2012|work=Wall Street Journal|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10001424052702303561504577492413851079538|accessdate=June 27, 2012}}</ref> Jicai also noted that no mention was made of the people who later harassed the family, nor was there any mention of an incident where her brother was attacked and beaten.<ref name=family />
Zhang Kai, a lawyer from Beijing, told Deng Jiyuan he would look into filing a lawsuit against the township government.<ref name=SCMP /> "To force a woman who is seven months pregnant to have an abortion is a serious violation of the law," he said. "At the very least it should be considered willful and malicious injury." Zhang said he hoped the case would cause people to rethink China's population control policies.<ref name=suspends /> On June 29, he announced that he was officially representing the family and would seek the help of other lawyers to get the case heard in criminal court. However, he acknowledged that doing so would be difficult. "China's family planning departments are above the law," he explained. "Even when they do something illegal it is rare for them to be held responsible."<ref name=resurfaces /><ref name=sue>{{cite news|title=Forced Abortion Father to Sue|date=June 29, 2012|work=Radio Free Asia|url=http://www.rfa.org/english/news/china/lawsuit-06292012112222.html|accessdate=June 30, 2012}}</ref> In response to the lawsuit threats, local officials cancelled a planned meeting to discuss the living stipend, saying they would wait for Jiyuan's return to Zeng Jia Township.<ref name=sue />
[[File:Danshan Nongguang Village Bulletin board.jpg|thumb|left|340px|A community bulletin board in Nonguang Village, [[Sichuan province]] keeps track of the town's female population, listing recent births by name and noting that several thousand yuan of fines for unauthorized births remain unpaid from the previous year]] Judge Xie Xue told reporters that forced abortion would not be classified as [[homicide]] or [[kidnapping]], but could qualify as an intentional injury crime. In cases where complications arose after the abortion, such as Feng's, the injury could be considered a serious offense bearing a possible penalty of three to ten years in prison.<ref name=inspection /> However, ''[[The Wall Street Journal]]'' said a legal remedy was unlikely, noting that a 2008 decision by the [[Supreme People's Court]] indicated that litigation could not be based on specific provisions of the [[Constitution of the People's Republic of China|constitution]]. Furthermore, family planning law does not have any provision for damages awarded to victims of abuse by government officials.<ref name=fewoptions>{{cite news|title=The Law on Forced Abortion in China: Few Options for Victims|date=July 4, 2012|work=The Wall Street Journal|author=Stanley Lubman|url=https://blogs.wsj.com/chinarealtime/2012/07/04/the-law-on-forced-abortion-in-china-few-options-for-victims/|accessdate=July 17, 2012}}</ref>
On July 2, Zhang submitted an official request for the Ankang police to file a case and investigate the officials involved.<ref name=deal>{{cite news|title=Forced abortion case ends as deal reached|author=Yan Shuang|date=July 11, 2012|work=Global Times|url=http://www.globaltimes.cn/content/720323.shtml|accessdate=July 11, 2012}}</ref> Subsequently, Deng returned home and decided to negotiate with local authorities. On July 10, the family agreed to settle out of court for 70,600 yuan (~$11,200 USD). Additionally, the township agreed to pay Feng's medical bills if she contracted a disease from the abortion.<ref name=deal /> "I've given up legal appeals and agreed to take the compensation offered by the township government," Deng remarked. "We just want our normal life back."<ref name=deal /> He added, "It has never been about the money. As ordinary people, we can no longer take the pressure from all sides of the society".<ref>{{cite news|title=China pays for forced abortion|agency=Associated Press|work=The Province|date=July 12, 2012|url=https://theprovince.com/news/China+pays+forced+abortion/6921788/story.html|accessdate=July 17, 2012}}</ref> Zhang said the family gave up on pursuing criminal charges because local law enforcement was uncooperative, explaining that "if the prosecutors don't fulfill their responsibilities [to press charges], it's impossible to do."<ref name=settlement /> An official told [[Xinhua News Agency|Xinhua]], China's official state news agency, that the government was committed to providing for the family's financial needs if they should encounter future financial difficulties and that the government would also provide medical care for the Dengs' ailing mother.<ref>{{cite news|title=Forced abortion case settled after family is paid|agency=Xinhua|work=China Daily|date=July 11, 2012|url=http://www.chinadaily.com.cn/china/2012-07/11/content_15569665.htm|accessdate=July 11, 2012}}</ref>
Zhang said the compensation could not make up for a lifetime of "spiritual pain" and remarked that 70,000 yuan could not compensate for a lost life.<ref>Agence France-Presse, (July 11, 2012), "[http://www.news.com.au/world/women-gets-11k-for-late-abortion/story-fndir2ev-1226423929239 Chinese woman compensated for forced late abortion]". Retrieved October 23, 2012</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Chinese officials agree payout for family of woman forced to have abortion|author=Tania Branigan|date=July 11, 2012|work=The Guardian|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2012/jul/11/chinese-payout-woman-forced-abortion|accessdate=July 11, 2012|location=London}}</ref> "In terms of compensation, the word satisfaction doesn’t even enter the equation," Jiyuan remarked. "But this is the result, so we just have to accept it."<ref name=promised>{{cite news|title=China: Forced-Abortion Victim Promised $11,200, but Family Fears for Life|author=Hannah Beech|date=July 13, 2012|work=TIME|url=http://world.time.com/2012/07/13/china-forced-abortion-victim-awarded-11200-fears-for-life|accessdate=July 17, 2012}}</ref> Reactions on Chinese social media were mixed, and some commented that the government had gotten too lenient a consequence.<ref name=settlement /> International activists said the settlement of Feng's case was just the beginning of the fight to end the one-child policy, with [[Bob Fu]] of ChinaAid remarking, "The bottom line is there are hundreds and thousands of [cases like] Feng Jianmei."<ref>{{cite news|title=China Reaches Settlement in Forced Abortion Case|work=VOA News|publisher=Voice of America|date=July 11, 2012|url=http://www.voanews.com/content/china-reaches-cash-settlement-in-forced-abortion-case/1382464.html|accessdate=July 11, 2012}}</ref> As of July 13, the family had not received the promised compensation and Jiyuan told reporters he was not sure if it would ever come.<ref name=promised />
===Harassment and surveillance of family members=== In the weeks after Feng Jianmei's story went public, the family suffered from what Zhang called "state-backed harassment."<ref name=harassment>{{cite news|title=China forced-abortion woman suffering state harassment, lawyer says|author=Tania Branigan|date=June 26, 2012|work=The Guardian|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2012/jun/26/china-forced-abortion-woman-feng?newsfeed=true|accessdate=June 26, 2012|location=London}}</ref> The harassment started when Deng Jiyuan attempted to go to [[Beijing]] to talk with a lawyer and do a television interview.<ref name=pressure /><ref name=missing>{{cite news|title=Forced-abortion case husband goes missing|author=Zhuang Pinghui|work=South China Morning Post|date=June 26, 2012|page=1|url=http://www.scmp.com/portal/site/SCMP/menuitem.2c913216495213d5df646910cba0a0a0|accessdate=June 26, 2012|subscription=yes}}</ref> Jiyuan's travel attempt was stopped by "more than 100 people and a dozen cars," according to Deng Jicai. Then, "a man suddenly appeared and kicked my brother in the stomach."<ref name=harassed>Didi Tang, (June 26, 2012), "[http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2012/06/26/china-forced-abortion-case_n_1627394.html? Family in forced abortion case harassed in China]", ''Associated Press''. Retrieved October 23, 2012.</ref> After Jiyuan was interviewed by [[Stern (magazine)|''Stern'' magazine]] on June 22, the harassment from the government became worse,<ref name=missing /> with Jiyuan stating that he was subsequently followed by "local officials and thugs" everywhere he went, even the bathroom.<ref name=missing /> He then disappeared from public sight on June 24, only phoning home on June 26 to say he was safe, but his whereabouts remained unknown.<ref name=harassment />
On June 29, Jiyuan reappeared in Beijing, telling reporters, "I came to Beijing in search of help."<ref name=resurfaces>{{cite news|title=Father in One-Child Saga Resurfaces in Beijing|author=Josh Chin|work=Wall Street Journal|date=June 29, 2012|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10001424052702304830704577496550834930224|accessdate=June 30, 2012}}</ref> He said that he had made two unsuccessful attempts to flee from custody before succeeding on his third try.<ref name=escape>{{cite news|title=Husband of forced abortion victim tells of his escape from Chinese officials|author=Malcolm Moore|date=July 1, 2012|work=The Telegraph|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/asia/cambodia/9368131/Husband-of-forced-abortion-victim-tells-of-his-escape-from-Chinese-officials.html|accessdate=July 2, 2012|location=London}}</ref> While his official monitors were on the phone, Jiyuan fled to a friend's home, where he remained for two days. He removed the [[subscriber identity module|sim card]] and battery from his cell phone to prevent being tracked. "I did not sleep or get any new clothes, I could not risk being arrested," he recalled.<ref name=escape /> They rented a car and drove to Beijing, and Jiyuan recalled that "I assumed there would be government people at the train station."<ref name=escape /> Whenever they neared police officers, he would get out of the car and walk to prevent being spotted.<ref name=escape />
Other family members were also reportedly followed and harassed by government officials. Protestors converged outside the hospital where Feng was staying, carrying a banner that read "severely beat the traitors and expel them."<ref name=harassed /> Local media reported that the local government had organized the protest.<ref name=resurfaces /> About a dozen guards patrolled outside Feng's hospital room for two weeks, following family members wherever they went.<ref name=harassed /> "We feel like prisoners," remarked Deng Jicai.<ref name=missing /> Supporters of the family allege that local officials were also engaged in an online smear campaign against the family.<ref name=harassment /> "The whole family feels very depressed and pressured," said Jicai.<ref name=harassment /> On June 26, a visiting family member had their tires slashed.<ref name=harassment /> A spokesperson for the Shaanxi provincial government called the allegations of harassment unfounded rumors.<ref name=harassment /> However, Liang Zhongtang, an independent researcher, said it was common for people who seek outside help to be harassed by local governments. He speculated that the township government was trying to prevent further media coverage of the case.<ref name=harassed /> On July 13, Jiyuan said that he remained concerned over his family's future safety, noting: "There are rumors on the street that after this thing calms down, when people are not paying attention to us anymore, they [the officials who were punished for approving the abortion] will kill my family."<ref name=promised />
Later, when asked if she still wanted to have another child, Feng told ''The New York Times'', "That depends on how my body recovers. Yes, if I can get my health back."<ref name="pressure" />
==Domestic and international response==
===Official response and calls to reform in China=== On June 27, the [[National Population and Family Planning Commission]] announced it would conduct a review of family planning enforcement country-wide. As part of the review, ten inspection teams would be sent to nineteen different [[Provinces of the People's Republic of China|provinces]] to review the practices of local offices,<ref name=review>{{cite news|title=Family Planning Authorities Order Review of Local Enforcement|author=Lin Yunshi|date=June 28, 2012|work=Caixin Online|url=http://english.caixin.com/2012-06-28/100405238.html|accessdate=June 30, 2012}}</ref> and that the teams would be charged with settling disputes and would distribute [[Birth control|contraceptives]].<ref name=review /> Commission director Wang Xia said the inspection was of great importance, remarking that "even slight carelessness in law enforcement [damages] the image of the Party and the country."<ref name=inspection>{{cite news|title=Abortion scandal prompts nationwide inspection|author=Liu Linlin|date=June 29, 2012|work=Global Times|url=http://www.globaltimes.cn/content/717868.shtml|accessdate=June 30, 2012}}</ref> Xia said the review would aim to "strengthen the day-to-day management of services, avoid the use of violence and prevent abuses of administrative enforcement"; he placed a special emphasis on the "social maintenance fees" collected from policy violators.<ref name=inspection /><ref name=review /> Simultaneously, the commission declared that fines collected for future violations could no longer be spent at the local level, but instead would go into a general fund.<ref name=review /> He Yafu described the campaign as an attempt by the commission to restore public trust that had been badly damaged by Feng's forced abortion.<ref name=inspection />
On July 3, 2012, an open letter by three members of the Development Research Center of the State Council, a [[think tank]] that advises the Chinese ruling cabinet, was published in the group's newspaper, ''China Economic Times''. In the letter they called for "adjustments" to be made to the one-child policy "as soon as possible".<ref name=academics>{{cite news|title=Chinese academics urge end to one-child policy|author=Tom Phillips|work=The Telegraph|date=July 5, 2012|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/asia/china/9378679/Chinese-academics-urge-end-to-one-child-policy.html|accessdate=July 6, 2012|location=London}}</ref> The group advised that "an opening up of the two-child option to all should be considered."<ref name=think-tank /> Demographer Liang Zhongtang said the letter was likely the start of a gradual shift in policy, but that a sudden shift was very unlikely.<ref name=academics /> Although there was no explicit mention of Feng Jianmei in the letter, multiple news sources drew a connection between the timing of the two events.<ref name=academics /><ref name=think-tank>{{cite news|title=Think Tank Calls China to Adjust One-Child Policy|author=Josh Chin|date=July 3, 2012|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10001424052702304211804577504360440496118|accessdate=July 6, 2012|work=The Wall Street Journal}}</ref> Writing for ''[[The New Yorker]]'', [[Evan Osnos]] said that "pressure for change of China’s one-child policy seems to be mounting" in the wake of Feng's case.<ref>{{cite news|title=Two Children, No "Cults": Chinese Family Advertising|author=Evan Osnos|date=July 5, 2012|work=The New Yorker|url=http://www.newyorker.com/online/blogs/evanosnos/2012/07/families-reject-cults.html|accessdate=July 17, 2012}}</ref> On July 5, a group of fifteen scholars released an own open letter to the [[National People's Congress]] arguing that change to family planning law was "imperative".<ref name=deal /><ref name=scholars>{{cite news|title=Chinese Scholars Call for Revision of One-Child Policy|author=Josh Chin|date=July 6, 2012|work=The Wall Street Journal|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10001424052702303962304577509062660508548|accessdate=July 7, 2012}}</ref> The letter mentioned research indicating economic consequences of continuing the one-child policy, but focused on human rights issues, mentioning Feng by name. "Behind these incidents are clear limitations and defects in the nation's family planning laws," read the letter.<ref name=scholars /> Liang Jianzhang, one of the letter's signers, told a reporter "From an economic perspective, the one-child policy is irrational. From a human-rights perspective, it's even less rational."<ref name=scholars />
===International reaction=== Feng Jianmei's ordeal brought increased scrutiny to China's abortion and population-control policies. International commentators were highly critical of the government's role in Feng's abortion. "Feng Jianmei's story demonstrates how the One-Child Policy continues to sanction violence against women every day", said [[Chai Ling]] of the NGO All Girls Allowed.<ref name=uproar /> Women's Rights Without Frontiers' president Reggie Littlejohn stated "no legitimate government would commit or tolerate such an act. Those who are responsible should be prosecuted for crimes against humanity."<ref name=WRWF /> In a press release, the Christian [[Alliance Defense Fund]] called Feng's case "nothing less than a crime against humanity" and asked American political leaders to formally condemn the act.<ref>{{cite press release|title=ADF calls on U.S. leaders to condemn forced abortion atrocity in China|date=June 13, 2012|publisher=Alliance Defense Fund|url=http://www.adfmedia.org/News/PRDetail/5567|accessdate=June 24, 2012|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://archive.is/20130223165436/http://www.adfmedia.org/News/PRDetail/5567|archivedate=February 23, 2013|df=}}</ref> The [[World Evangelical Alliance]] said it was "outraged" by the incident and asked the Chinese government to "ensure that these tragic incidents are prevented from happening in the future".<ref>{{cite press release|title=WEA Was Shocked by the Forced Abortion of a Baby at Seven Months in Shaanxi, China|publisher=World Evangelical Alliance|date=June 17, 2012|url=http://www.worldea.org/news/4032/the-world-evangelical-alliance-was-shocked-by-the-forced-abortion-of-a-baby-at-seven-months-in-shaanxi-china|accessdate=June 25, 2012}}</ref>
On July 5, [[European Parliament]] passed a resolution condemning both the treatment of Feng and forced abortions in general, "especially in the context of the one-child policy".<ref name=EU>{{cite news|title=EU Parliament condemns China forced abortions|work=Philippine Daily Inquirer|agency=Agence France-Presse|date=July 6, 2012|url=http://newsinfo.inquirer.net/224353/eu-parliament-condemns-china-forced-abortions|accessdate=July 7, 2012}}</ref> The resolution also requested that forced abortion be added the agenda for the next bilateral human rights dialogue with China.<ref>{{cite web|title=Joint motion for a resolution on the forced abortion scandal in China|date=July 4, 2012|publisher=European Parliament|url=http://www.europarl.europa.eu/sides/getDoc.do?type=MOTION&reference=P7-RC-2012-388&language=EN|accessdate=July 7, 2012}}</ref> Additionally, some [[Members of the European Parliament]] (MEPs) requested an independent investigation into forced abortion and infanticide in China.<ref name=EU /> A few days later, MEP [[Lojze Peterle]] opined that Chinese family planning law violates provisions outlined by the [[United Nations]] in the [[International Conference on Population and Development]]. He said the resolution passed by parliament gives the [[European Commission]] a "clear mandate" to withdraw funds from any organization potentially involved in aiding coercive practices in China, citing the [[International Planned Parenthood Federation]] and [[Marie Stopes International]] as two potential targets.<ref>{{cite web|title=Chinese forced abortion 'inhuman and degrading'|author=Alojz Peterle|date=July 11, 2012|publisher=Public Service Europe|url=http://www.publicserviceeurope.com/article/2205/chinese-forced-abortion-inhuman-and-degrading|accessdate=July 11, 2012|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120723060730/http://www.publicserviceeurope.com/article/2205/chinese-forced-abortion-inhuman-and-degrading|archivedate=July 23, 2012|df=}}</ref>
On July 9, the [[United States House Foreign Affairs Subcommittee on Africa, Global Health, Global Human Rights and International Organizations|Human Rights Subcommittee]] of the [[United States House of Representatives]] convened a hearing on the one-child policy prompted by Feng's story. In his opening remarks, chairman [[Chris Smith (New Jersey politician)|Chris Smith]] called the one-child policy "a nightmarish 'brave new world' ... where women are psychologically wounded, girls fall victim to [[sex-selective abortion]] ... and most children grow up without brothers or sisters, aunts or uncles or cousins".<ref>{{cite web|title=Forced Abortion at 7 Months of Feng Jianmei Sparks Global Outrage – and Concern|date=July 9, 2012|author=Chris Smith|url=http://chrissmith.house.gov/UploadedFiles/2012-07-09_Continued_Human_Rights_Attacks_on_Families_in_China.pdf|accessdate=July 11, 2012}}</ref> He said that because of Feng, people were "finally seeing the gruesome reality of China's one-child policy".<ref name=newpressure>{{cite news|title=Gruesome picture puts new pressure on China over one-child policy|author=Cheryl Wetzstein|work=Washington Times|date=July 9, 2012|url=http://www.washingtontimes.com/news/2012/jul/9/gruesome-picture-puts-new-pressure-on-china-over-o/|accessdate=July 11, 2012}}</ref> Congressman [[Joseph R. Pitts]] agreed, saying, "It now seems that consensus in China is building towards reforming the policy."<ref name=newpressure /> Committee witnesses called for a number of responses such as restricting [[United Nations Population Fund]] outlays and encouraging U.S. corporations doing business in China to reject the country's family-planning practices at their facilities.<ref name=newpressure />
===International media coverage=== Feng's case became a focal point for newspaper editorials against China's one-child policy and abortion in general. Opponents of the one-child policy said the case is a potential turning point in the efforts to end the rule.<ref name=think-tank /> On June 26, [[Reuters]] said the story had sparked "a firestorm domestically and around the world",<ref name=Reuters>{{cite news|title=China sacks official, punishes others in forced abortion case|agency=Reuters|date=June 26, 2012|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2012/06/27/us-china-abortion-idUSBRE85Q02P20120627|accessdate=June 27, 2012}}</ref> explaining, "Feng Jianmei's abortion was portrayed in the Chinese and international press as an example of the extreme measures some officials would take to control China's population, even if it meant breaking Chinese law."<ref name=Reuters /> A story in ''The Wall Street Journal'' remarked that the case "dramatize[s] the harshness of the one-child policy."<ref name=fewoptions /> The incident prompted Evan Osnos, the ''New Yorker'' writer'','' to create a feature piece titled "Abortion and Politics in China." Osnos said that "the Feng case is emblematic of some of the most inflammatory issues on Chinese public life", including money, government corruption, the household registration system, and of course family planning, and that "the case is a dramatic demonstration of exactly why the Communist Party had reason to be afraid of the Internet."<ref name=NewYorker>{{cite news|title=Abortion and Politics in China|author=Evan Osnos|date=June 15, 2012|work=The New Yorker|url=http://www.newyorker.com/online/blogs/evanosnos/2012/06/abortion-and-politics-in-china.html|accessdate=June 25, 2012}}</ref>
On June 23, ''[[The Economist]]'' featured a story on China’s one-child policy, focusing on Feng's forced abortion and how the internet was changing power dynamics in China. "Three years ago, Ms. Feng's suffering might have gone unnoticed ... But her relatives uploaded the graphic pictures onto the internet, and soon microblogs had flashed them to millions of people across the country," writes the article's author.<ref name=brutal>{{cite news|title=The brutal truth|work=The Economist|date=June 23, 2012|url=http://www.economist.com/node/21557369|accessdate=June 24, 2012}}</ref> Wang Songlian, a researcher for [[Chinese Human Rights Defenders]], said it was certain that the internet had made discussion of Feng's case possible, but she called the officials' punishments "isolated" and said "government officials are virtually immune in using violence and carrying out the policy by force. We've not seen any significant [change] in holding officials accountable."<ref>{{cite news|title=Chinese officials who pushed woman into late-term abortion 'punished'|date=June 28, 2012|author=Daniel Bardsley|work=The National|url=http://www.thenational.ae/news/world/chinese-officials-who-pushed-woman-into-late-term-abortion-punished|accessdate=June 28, 2012}}</ref>
A June 22 editorial in ''[[The Australian]]'' argued against the one-child policy, stating that Feng's case "one small example of the terrible costs of China's longstanding population control regime".<ref>{{cite news|title=China's one-child policy no 'solution' to climate change|author=Dan Ryan|date=June 22, 2012|url=http://www.theaustralian.com.au/news/world/chinas-one-child-policy-no-solution-to-climate-change/story-e6frg6ux-1226404756438|accessdate=June 25, 2012|subscription=yes|work=The Australian}}</ref> A June 25 editorial in the ''[[Herald Sun]]'', which examined family planning in general, said that Feng "personifies the end game of forced population limits".<ref>{{cite news|title=Family planning for the 21st century|author=Wendy Tuohy|work=Herald Sun|date=June 25, 2012|url=http://www.heraldsun.com.au/ipad/family-planning-for-the-21st-century/story-fnbdxfy6-1226406982683|accessdate=June 25, 2012}}</ref>
Several commentators have compared Feng Jianmei to [[Liu Yang (astronaut)|Liu Yang]], who was in the news at roughly the same time for becoming the first Chinese female in space. On June 17, the ''Tea Leaf Nation'' blog published a story entitled "Netizens Reflect As One Chinese Woman Touches Heaven, Another Hell".<ref name=netizens>{{cite web|title=Netizens Reflect As One Chinese Woman Touches Heaven, Another Hell|author=Liz Carter|work=Tea Leaf Nation|date=June 17, 2012|url=http://tealeafnation.com/2012/06/netizens-reflect-as-one-chinese-woman-touches-heaven-another-hell/|accessdate=June 25, 2012|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120623133934/http://tealeafnation.com/2012/06/netizens-reflect-as-one-chinese-woman-touches-heaven-another-hell/|archivedate=June 23, 2012|df=}}</ref> The story, focused on a widely distributed Sina Weibo post, features pictures of Feng and Liu side by side, and the blogger wrote in the caption "The stark contrast between the fates of [the] two women ... is the clearest illustration of the torn state of this nation."<ref name=netizens /> The post was quickly re-tweeted by famous blogger [[Han Han]]. By the time the government deleted both posts, the information had already been shared 70,000 times in the first 24 hours.<ref name=netizens /> ''The [[International Herald Tribune]]'' immediately picked up the story, stating, "The gruesome abortion incident was cast this weekend against China’s successful launching of its first female astronaut. The sad irony of the two women’s situations was not lost on Chinese netizens."<ref>{{cite news|title=Two Women and Two Trajectories in China|author=Mark McDonald|work=International Herald Tribune|date=June 17, 2012|url=http://rendezvous.blogs.nytimes.com/2012/06/16/two-women-and-two-trajectories-in-china/|accessdate=June 25, 2012}}</ref> Two days later, the ''Global Post'' published the story and commented, "leave it to Sina Weibo to point out what's important",<ref name=astronauts>{{cite news|title=Chinese women: from astronauts to forced abortions|author=Emily Lodish|date=June 19, 2012|work=Global Post|url=http://www.globalpost.com/dispatches/globalpost-blogs/chatter/china-chinese-women-astronauts-forced-abortions|accessdate=June 24, 2012}}</ref> explaining that the juxtaposition of the two new stories "[highlights] China's current troubled and contradictory state ... Some Chinese women get launched into space, others receive injections that kill their unborn child."<ref name=astronauts />
Journalist [[Andrew Bolt]] used Feng's case to editorialize against abortion in Australia, writing, "Deng Jiyuan has shamed the tyrants of Beijing. But ... he shames us here as well."<ref name=baby>{{cite news|title=Baby, it's a crying shame|author=Andrew Bolt|date=June 18, 2012|work=Herald Sun|url=http://www.heraldsun.com.au/opinion/baby-its-a-crying-shame/story-e6frfhqf-1226398054333|accessdate=June 24, 2012}}</ref> He compared Feng's abortion to famous cases in Australia and concluded that the main difference was the graphic pictures of Feng's baby.<ref name=baby />
''[[Asia Times Online]]'' featured Feng's story in an editorial titled "China's addiction to birth planning". Author Peter Lee remarked that it was "disturbing" how many resources the township devoted to persuading Feng, quoting an official as saying, "On that day, pretty much all of the township leadership and relevant staff all went [to get Feng to the hospital]."<ref name=addiction>{{cite news|title=China's addiction to birth planning|author=Peter Lee|work=Asia Times Online|date=June 26, 2012|url=http://www.atimes.com/atimes/China/NF27Ad01.html|accessdate=June 26, 2012}}</ref> He concluded that the way the case was handled provides strong evidence that at least some of China's leaders are anxious to end the one-child policy.<ref name=addiction /> In contrast, an editorial published in ''[[The Peninsula (newspaper)|The Peninsula]]'' argued that the case showed China's leaders were losing their ability to control local authorities.<ref>{{cite news|title=Editorial: Headcount copping|date=June 29, 2012|work=The Peninsula|url=http://www.thepeninsulaqatar.com/qatar/199351-editorial-headcount-copping-.html|accessdate=June 30, 2012|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://archive.is/20130204042008/http://www.thepeninsulaqatar.com/qatar/199351-editorial-headcount-copping-.html|archivedate=February 4, 2013|df=}}</ref>
He Yafu says the controversy has damaged the public image of one-child policy in China.<ref name=brutal /> Journalist [[Fareed Zakaria]] suggested there were signs that the Chinese government was softening its rules, noting the large number of prominent citizens who spoke out against Feng's abortion. Zakaria wrote, "Even a few years ago, it would have taken a very brave Chinese thinker to pose that question in public."<ref name=change>{{cite news|title=Could China's one-child policy change?|author=Fareed Zakaria|date=July 9, 2012|work=Fareed Zakaria GPS|publisher=CNN|url=http://globalpublicsquare.blogs.cnn.com/2012/07/09/could-chinas-one-child-policy-change/|accessdate=July 11, 2012}}</ref> However, he said that formal change would be impossible before a change in leadership occurred, and even then would "take much courage".<ref name=change />
A July 17 piece in ''[[The Huffington Post]]'' said that the case "captured the public imagination in China because it exemplifies broader systemic issues".<ref name=caught>{{cite news|title=Chinese Villager Caught in US Abortion Debate|author=Julian Baird Gewirtz|author2=Rachel Kauder Nalebuff|date=July 17, 2012|work=Huffington Post|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/julian-baird-gewirtz/china-abortion_b_1672917.html|accessdate=July 20, 2012}}</ref> Feng's case had been cited by both [[pro-life]] and [[pro-choice]] advocates in the United States in support of their causes; for pro-life advocates, the case represented "the kind of 'federally endorsed' abortions that they fear may lie in store for the United States",<ref name=caught /> while for pro-choice advocates, "[Feng] should have been granted a choice in the first place."<ref name=caught />
==References== {{reflist|30em}}
==External links== *[http://www.weibo.com/2830059422/ynFTDzBze Original Sina Weibo post] that started the controversy (text in Chinese) *[http://www.europarl.europa.eu/sides/getDoc.do?type=TA&reference=P7-TA-2012-0301&language=EN&ring=P7-RC-2012-0388 Text] of resolution passed by the European Parliament *[http://foreignaffairs.house.gov/hearings/view/?1452 Witness statements] from US House hearing **[http://chrissmith.house.gov/UploadedFiles/2012-07-09_Continued_Human_Rights_Attacks_on_Families_in_China.pdf Opening statement] by congressman Chris Smith *[https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-asia-china-18778597 Story] about Pan Chunyan, a woman who came forward with her story of being forced into abortion while eight months pregnant after seeing the outrage caused by Feng's abortion *Editorials about and/or inspired by Feng Jianmei's forced abortion **[http://www.globaltimes.cn/content/714595.shtml Editorial] in ''Global Times'' (China) condemning forced abortion **[http://www.atimes.com/atimes/China/NF27Ad01.html Editorial] in ''Asian Times'' (Hong Kong/Thailand) arguing against the one-child policy **[https://calgaryherald.com/opinion/Martinuk+China+forced+abortion+should+make+reflect/6857331/story.html Editorial] in ''The Calgary Herald'' (Canada) arguing against the one-child policy and abortion in general **[https://www.nytimes.com/2012/07/05/opinion/forced-abortion-in-china.html Editorial] in ''The New York Times'' (USA) by abortion-rights activist Nancy Northup condemning forced abortion **[https://archive.is/20130204042008/http://www.thepeninsulaqatar.com/qatar/199351-editorial-headcount-copping-.html Editorial] in ''The Peninsula'' (Qatar) arguing that China's leaders are losing control over the country
